sean liu wrote:
> Hi,
> I'm a java programmer who is now using TDD and junit. In my current
> project, we are using webwork/spring/hibernate trioes.And in architecture
> view, there is a web controller/ service / dao three layer logic separation.
> And there is another important layer called domain model. Sevice layer
> usually delegate to domain model to complete it's service and it should be a
> thin layer. My question is how to test the web && service && domain
> model.After i have tested a particular business logic in domain logic, do i
> need to test corresponding conditions in service layer and web
> layer.For example, in traditional auction application(citing caveatemptor
> application in book "Hibernate In Action"):

I didn't read your code, but here's a short answer to your question.

When I write web applications in Java, my "Data Access Layer" is a bunch 
of interfaces called XXXRepository. Each interface provides access to an 
Aggregate Root of objects (see _Domain Driven Design_ for more 
information on aggregate roots). This way I can test the Business Logic 
layer with Test Doubles (search for "test automation patterns meszaros") 
standing in for the Repository interfaces. By doing this, I can run all 
those tests in memory. Only a handful of the Repository tests actually 
touch a real database.

I also add an Application Layer that knows about the application, but 
not HTTP/HTML. This way I can test my application with a Java API that's 
easily adapted to the web. Most of my tests go through this API with 
only a handful of tests that check whether I convert HTTP requests to 
Application requests properly.

For a longer answer, read _JUnit Recipes_.
